criticReviews.criticPost: Making a near-narrative reinvention look effortless, and expanding its visual vocabulary into ever-more imaginative flourishes, Hannibal's third outing secures its place as network television's greatest current triumph.
Hannibal's audience must also juggle tough questions along with macabre and stunning imagery.
It was a delicious episode.
Hannibal remains a show that flirts dangerously with being very silly, however it struts about with such devil-may-care panache that it gets away with pretty much everything it wants to.
No series, Twin Peaks included, has quite managed to be as deadly serious but also as winkingly ludicrous, so that you can't easily separate one mode of presentation from the other.
It's possible, of course, that I love the show because it confirms my worst suspicions about food culture.
After two years in the role, Mikkelsen has outgrown the Anthony Hopkins film portrayal and made this charismatic monster his own.

Here at the start of season 3, the many references to Dr. Lecter as the devil take on a new quality, given the fact that, for the first time since the series began, we are treated to a Hannibal Lecter who seems far more human than ever before.

While I'm as anxious as everyone else to see what happened to Will and the others, Hannibal himself remains a fascinating character and even without Will physically being there, his presence was felt.
Hannibal begins its third season in a fog, but eventually makes this much clear: We know how this story ends, but the journey to that destination can still be bloody fun.
Bonsoir, Hannibal. I missed you.
Hannibal Season 3 didn't exactly start of with a bang as it did last year, but I'm intrigued enough by what we were shown (and what we weren't shown) to have enjoyed the premiere fully.
Knowing that we can safely root for Will makes it so much easier to plug into Hannibal.
The killers on Hannibal are far less interested in slaking violent urges than they are in producing beautifully destroyed corpses, and generating a kind of public art.
I am just enthusiastic to have Hannibal back in my life-disconcerting nightmares and all.
The precise and surgical control Hannibal has always exercised is starting to unravel and it's exciting to see how his downfall eventually unfolds.
Hannibal uses its source materials in a way that creates a wholly new work that still feels like the original.
Hannibal drips with style... it's in that disturbing beauty that the show finds its visceral and intellectual power...
It is a magnificently macabre drama that looks and feels like absolutely nothing else on TV.
It's difficult to love a show that seems to be trying to hard to be impenetrable to viewers to the point that it's practically begging to be canceled with such uninviting storytelling.
The true brilliance of this show lies in the cues it takes from Hannibal's high aesthetic standards.
What makes Hannibal such an essential and worthwhile ongoing project is that it never loses sight of its moral equation, even as it becomes untethered from reality.

Welcome back, Fannibals! It's been a long wait, but Bryan Fuller's incredible, dark and beautifully haunting take on Dr. Lecter has finally returned, and if the premiere episode is any indication, we're in for one hell of a season of Hannibal.
Hannibal is the rare network show with an utterly unique visual palette - even if it's one many might find distinctly unpalatable.

With the first two episodes of season two of Bryan Fuller's brilliant reimagining of Thomas Harris' Hannibal... the creators of what I considered to be the best network drama of 2013 set the stage to possibly top their first remarkable season.
The psychological cat-and-mouse games the characters play are more interesting and a welcome respite from the intense, horrifying serial killer stories.
Hannibal's second season elevates the surprisingly-high bar set by the first - creating binge-worthy television that makes you, like the titular character, covet for more.
If you're not watching Hannibal, you're missing out on one of the finest, most viscerally entertaining programs television (network or cable) has to offer.

The show raises many of [its] concepts to high art. It's a testament to Fuller's writing, Slade's vision, and the work of the many talented actors in this series. It all makes for a delicious opening course to the show's second season.
Per usual, this is horror creativity at its finest.
Having used its hiatus to miraculous effect, the show... is much better than it once was, perhaps the guiltiest pleasure on television at this time.
From the unofficial slogan of the show ("Eat the rude") to the food-theme episode titles ("Amuse-Bouche," "Potage"), [Bryan] Fuller leavens the grimness with just enough irony.
At its heart, Hannibal is one of TV's best examinations of the nature of evil, but it's also a dark pulp thriller, with a rich sense of momentum and spine-tingling fun.

Assuming that Hannibal manages to keep going, I firmly believe that this show will serve as the proverbial wrecking ball in demolishing the final barrier in the cable/network divide. Hyperbole be damned-it's that much of a game-changer.
The premiere's opening whetted the appetite and got me ready for the twists and turns that were coming our way.
Everything ultimately boils down to Bryan Fuller's brilliant vision filled with luscious production design and beautifully macabre dreamscapes.
Hannibal is a terrifically performed, stylishly shot TV series that does, in stellar fashion, exactly what is sets out to do.
[It] is a feast of macabre freakishness, going beyond the realm of guilty pleasure in a sustained nightmare of horrific yet elegantly hypnotic design.
The show's greatest asset is its mastery of tone, a quality most shows don't have the time or inclination to get right.
Bryan Fuller's delicate rendering contains enough beautiful images and unexpected moments to operate a little longer, but this little lamb is perched on rickety legs.
It varies in narrative satisfaction, but is packed with cameos from the Thomas Harris texts and set under a shifting sky of horrific, magnetic beauty.
Will Graham does justice to his role as a male version of the Jodie Foster character and Mads Mikkelson is brilliantly icy and creepy as Lecter.
It was (and still is) the most beautifully designed and photographed series on television. Not what you expect from a show with such gruesome subject matter and grotesque murders.
The last half of "Hannibal"'s debut season is as good as anything on television.
Hannibal is promising to be mighty delicious. Mads Mikkelsen will see to that.
Hyperstylized and, at times, hypnotically beautiful, it's a nightmare masquerading as a dream, the rare cannibal story that has the smarts to back up its hunger for brains.
That's right: Creator Bryan Fuller has made Hannibal scary again.
The result is a challenging psychological thriller within a gripping crime procedural.
It quickly has become one of my absolute favorite new shows so far this year.
For the most part Hannibal suffers from the same fatal flaw as its main character: It takes itself so seriously that it's no fun at all..
If Hannibal can establish Lecter and Graham so well so quickly, it shouldn't take it long to develop the periphery.
Hannibal is the best new network drama of the 2012-13 season.
[This] prequel to The Silence of the Lambs manages to be engaging and haunting without being formulaic.
That's a problem with the show: It takes itself so seriously, yet is so far-fetched.
Hannibal is the most beautiful series on network TV, alarmingly so.
At times, this drama is absolutely transfixing, and I say that as someone who felt great weariness at the thought of watching one more show about murderers.
Hannibal isn't quite the sum of its admittedly evocative parts.

Creator Bryan Fuller and his team also deliver one of the richest visual experiences you'll see. Hannibal is pretty much the opposite of Fuller's Pushing Daisies in tone and in subject matter, but his flair for a great image remains.
At once beautiful and languorous, Hannibal unfolds with the logic of a terrifying dream.
It's a macabre dance that only promises to get more intense.
The good thing about this arson arc is that it opens the door wide open for a Chicago PD crossover.
It's simply stunning to me that Chicago Fire isn't recognized during awards season. The acting is top notch, the storytelling incredible and it's full of heart.
Wow, is it hot in here? Or is it just that STEAMING HOT ending of Tuesday night's Chicago Fire?
Michelle Forbes is SO good at playing bad, isn't she? Every time she comes into the Chief's office I actually tense up, wondering what decency she's going to shut down next.
The sooner we get back to telling compelling and emotionally driven stories rather than shock value plot points that will ultimately lead nowhere, the better Chicago Fire Season 2 will be.
Oz's Eammon Walker and House's Jesse Spencer are among the men and women who populate the show's Windy City firehouse, where all sorts of bland personal drama occurs in between flame-fighting.
Rescue Me got there first and went much deeper.
We'll definitely keep checking the temperature on Chicago Fire.
Everyone here is working from the same medium-grim setting, with medium-grim dialogue, which quickly drags the story and action into the still-smoldering ruins of other fire-and-rescue dramas.
There's nothing wrong with procedurals you can count on to entertain you for an hour a week.
None of [the characters are] very interesting, and it's actually kind of hard to tell them apart.
Fire is almost as drab as a pile of ash.
All the right elements are exactly where you'd expect them to be.
Chicago Fire is a easily the best new show for people who'd like nothing more than to curl up in front of the set and watch pretty people do heroic things.
The new NBC series is a garden-variety action procedural, with a crew of EZ-to-read characters and story lines that start at A and finish exactly where you expect them to, at Zzz.
The blazes aren't very convincing, and neither are the intrasquad dramas in Chicago Fire,
In all but title and character specifics, viewers have seen this show a dozen times before.
The real pain is in the scripts, so trite and earnestly predictable they should come with four-alarm cliche warnings.
For what it is -- another weekly look at flame-fighters and companion paramedics -- it's not half bad.
While viewers can delight in some familiar faces, the cast alone cannot resuscitate the shaky writing to make it a surefire hit.
Sometimes those stories even work.
It's a mark of just how mediocre this new fall TV season has been that a show as standard as Chicago Fire is one of its better offerings.
This is all professionally done, but straight-faced to a level just shy of self-parody, a Mad Libs script that isn't in on the joke.
Chicago Fire isn't bad, but it doesn't reach for anything beyond average.
All these pretty faces and tight abs (and skeleton-thin acting abilities) take you right out of the so-called reality of the series.
The good part is, Chicago PD does more than just rip straight from the headlines, it shows both sides.
It's nice to have some more female energy on the show.
We've already had our first three show crossover of the season!
Let's face it, the best part of Chicago PD is not the actual crimes, but the drama that surrounds the fabulous characters and this premiere didn't let us down.

The characters are nice to look at (too nice to be realistic, actually, but oh well), have satisfyingly heroic-yet-complicated backstories, and the action is fast and furious since this show lacks the courtroom aspect of the L&O shows.
The writers - led by Dick Wolf, the man behind Law & Order -skillfully ramp up the episodes into an action-movie-size thriller.
Is it the most original series on TV? Of course not. But if I can invest myself in the characters as much as I have with the Chi Fi gang, I'll be adding another show to my already too-full roster.

It's hard to imagine the series capturing the compelling, can't-watch-just-one magic that makes the Law & Order franchise so marathonable, but it moves just fast enough to keep you from changing the channel in search of an SVU re-run.
With the Chicago brand, NBC and Dick Wolf have managed to place a new spin on the standard procedural.
As executed, it almost seems like a parody of the genre.
The dialogue is predictable, the acting is marginal, and the plots are the swept-up leftovers from the Dick Wolf Idea Factory.
I never made it much beyond the first several episodes of Chicago Fire, and I'm not really in the market for another cop show. This one has some great characters and some heart-tugging stories.

Chicago P.D. is, in many ways, a throwback to an earlier, male-dominated era of crime shows, yet it carves out room for strong female characters who are good at their jobs and taken seriously by their colleagues - and the writers
It all makes you miss The Shield.
Distinguished primarily by its solid casting.
I enjoyed Chicago P.D. The new NBC procedural breathes enough to feel like it isn't a procedural at all.
While it may borrow heavily from some of the gritty cable dramas that have come before, Chicago PD is a surprisingly well done cop drama that builds upon Dick Wolf's large stable of procedurals.
It's not the best Dick Wolf show ever, but it'll do.
When did Wolf's work, which used to show some grace and wit, become this ugly, plodding and crass?
Producer/creator Wolf has shown he's still a master at melding ensemble casts, putting them in urgent inner city surroundings and dumping anyone who asks for too much money too fast.
The fact is that Chicago has a real crime problem and this tepid spin-off doesn't get close to addressing it in a fashion more realistic than a daytime soap.
Milking every known cop-show clich�, PD glorifies brutality on both sides of the law, and its mix of sadism and schmaltz is nauseating.
Unfortunately, Chicago P.D. is... a reminder, a breathy echo of other, much better shows. Many of which are available in affordable DVD packages and on various streaming services.
Everything about P.D., from it's cast of characters  to its sets and its vibe, seems to have been culled from the tired brain of somebody who binged on reruns of Hill Street Blues and NYPD Blue.
It is harmlessly watchable, to the extent that I will most likely watch this entire season in five-episode binge bursts.
Medical drama revives classic themes, bloody scenes.

There isn't anything groundbreaking about what Chicago Med (or Fire, or P.D.) is doing on an episode-by-episode basis, but that's not really the point. The point is to create solid dramas about the people whose lives revolve around saving others.
Wolf knows how to entertain us with his brand of gritty, pretty crime procedurals and with stronger character development, Chicago Med could improve its prognosis.

Overall, Chicago Med looks like it will be able to strike that sweet spot, balancing interesting medical cases with relatable human drama. Here's hoping that it not only finds it's way to the top of the Dick Wolf oeuvre.
A drama may not have to be dark to be good, but it does have to be, well, dramatic.
There's certainly nothing in the pilot, the only episode made available for review, to make a viewer sit up and take notice. Chicago Med is more of a show to comfortably fall asleep to.
Hey, compared to CBS's Code Black, Chicago Med is David Mamet stuff.
Even graded on the Dick Wolf Franchise Curve, Chicago Med is spectacularly underwhelming.
It's sort of the TV equivalent of comfort food - you know exactly what you're going to get when you start watching. And it's an OK way to spend and hour parked on the couch.
Unless it gets an injection of intelligence and creativity stat, Chicago Med will go down as ER for dummies.
Wolf has made a fortune for NBC with his Law & Order franchise, and Chicago Fire and Chicago PD suggest the formation of a second dynasty. But Chicago Med? Not so much.
Hopefully, Chicago Med will continue to stand on its own and will find a way to distinguish itself from other hospital dramas in the future.

In the end, what you're getting from Med is TV at its least demanding and most dispensable: It's not awful, but that's only because no one involved is expending the energy needed to reach the ranks of the truly terrible.
Viewers looking for the best new medical drama of this still young season can find it in Chicago Med. Then again, there are only two of them so far.

In a medium where drama junkies increasingly seem to need recaps to confirm (or explain) what they've seen, there's a place for a relatively old-fashioned medical show, especially one with a cast this appealing.
The writers fill Chicago Med with just enough character work to make the players interesting. So what if they lift every hospital drama cliche, from '60s classic Dr. Kildare to ER and Chicago Hope?

Chicago Med is so exactly what you expect it to be that there's practically no point describing it, a bad thing if you like your shows innovative and unpredictable, but a good thing if you can't get enough trauma room gore and dramatics.
It's your basic hospital ER drama with nothing really new to offer the genre. But like most, if not all of Wolf's shows (he's the creator of Law & Order), it's well done and has a strong cast.
Like Chicago Fire,Chicago Med is a really quick hour of television. Nothing lags, nothing bores, even the familiar.
This season may be about saying goodbyes, but for now I'm just happy to have Friday Night Lights back.
What's most remarkable about Friday Night Lights (outside of the quality of the writing and acting on the actual program) is how the show survived.
Even an episode that has all of the excitement of new beginnings still managed to tug at my heartstrings.
I'm generally impressed with how well the final season wrapped up.
Just watch the first two episodes and you will think one word ("Touchdown!") and remain emotionally riveted for the remaining 11 episodes of the final season.
In the end, Friday Night Lights managed to create striking moments out of the small and intimate... Texas forever, indeed.
I measure the quality of each episode based on my tear and cheer count, and this episode proved high in both. Ah, Dillon, Texas. How I have missed you.
Man, that was one fine, emotional, intelligent, and satisfying ending.
As always, it's good to be back in Dillon.
The series has several faults, but its strange concoction of emotions makes for some seriously compelling television.
While this season's arc may be presented too broadly, with a cast this strong it's difficult not to become ensnared in the raw emotions of Dillon, Texas.
For a show whose ratings never justified a second season, five seasons is an achievement to celebrate.

The show, and its survival, offers proof that quality can triumph in an industry driven by quantity and that even though necessity is the more fertile of the two, poetry can also be a fine mother to invention.
This is a show that's scored way more than it has faltered, and the opening episode suggests that streak will continue.
This show went to places that most shows aren't brave enough to go. For that reason, it'll forever be in the 'win' column.
This is a place, and a show, I will never want to leave. It feels like family. But we're lucky to have been given this much of their story. Underdogs to the end, these are my TV heroes.
I'm disappointed that the finale (and the entire season, I think) passed without a single "clear eyes, full hearts, can't lose." But coach Taylor's pep talk at practice was almost better.
FNL remains at the top of its game while also continuing to depict Texas as much more than a drawling board of cartoonish characters. That's basically a first on network television

Once again, I marvel at the fact that I even still have the privilege of writing about [it]. This show has defied the odds to a spectacular extent, and the fact that it is now in Season 4 is just awesome. And as usual, this show is awesome as well.
Bravo to a small masterpiece of an episode and a performance that was something altogether greater.
What's been so enthralling about this drama is not that it puts a fresh or unique spin on such issues; just that it takes us so fully into the minds of the characters involved in them.
Will this team even be in shape to play a game in next week's episode? We're entering a season where that's not even a given, and it's an exciting place to be.
The major story is among the most compelling season-long arcs this great, great drama has had, and all the other elements are all still in place, no matter what side of town Eric Taylor works.
Much that was great remains - in the cast members who carry over, and in the show's desire to detail the struggles of everyday life in small-town America.
Don't think on it too much. Just appreciate the top-tier quality.
These are fantastic characters with socio-economic backgrounds we rarely see in TV dramas, and that's one of the many things that makes "FNL" unique.
There's definitely a joy to this series, no matter how dire things get for its characters.

The real glory of Friday Night Lights is its uncanny ability to take something that shouldn't really make a TV show and squeeze stories and characters out of it that resonate beyond the dusty limits of Dillon County.
What has made FNL so riveting over its run is that while the town is football obsessed, nothing that happens between the goalposts is as compelling as the journey before the lights go on.
Friday Night Lights is rather brilliantly reinventing itself on the fly.
Several of the new characters experience the kind of wrenching/difficult life choices that we expect to see on this show, and the young actors do extremely good work.
[It] manages to retain its depth and heart-wrenching warmth despite a sea change in its structure and characters.
There aren't many high school shows - or shows, period - that get better in their fourth seasons.
Quirky, funny, smart, wonderful acting, surprise cameos by cherished actors (Steve Harris, The Practice), and a one-two punch by Chandler and Britton that is unbeatable. What's not to love?
With plenty of frankness and compassion, the Friday Night Lights writers continue to provide Friday night with its brightest light.

By the end of the opening hour, you're already engaged by Coach Taylor's challenge to turn the East Dillon stragglers into guys who can complete the phrase ''Clear eyes, full hearts, can't lose'' without mumbling.
I could probably watch an hour of Connie Britton and Kyle Chandler bantering every week, but Friday Night Lights offers much more. The cast members who started out good have only gotten better.
I've seen the entire season already on DIRECTV, and trust me, it only gets better, deeper, and richer.

If this is game over for Lights, the series goes out with its legacy intact, no matter what Nielsen says. For three seasons, the cast of little-known twentysomethings played their respective students with exceptional clarity, charm and authenticity.
Eric and Tami Taylor continue to have the most interesting and endearing relationship of any prime-time married couple.

As always, it's not the storylines that stood out on this show, but the moments -- the many times Friday Night Lights captures interactions between these characters that feel 100% genuine, even if you've seen versions of these stories before.
It creates a feeling, a mood, an atmosphere. When the show works, the plots recede to the background as "FNL" immerses you in the day-to-day lives of these characters.
Even a reduced Lights is better than most TV series, and a reduced Lights was all we were going to get.

The young actors were certainly as pretty as any 90210 alum, but they were called on to work from well-written scripts, to act in a manner that would be enticing to peer viewers but acceptable for adults who wanted something grittier. The mix worked.
Tyra (Adrianne Palicki), Landry (Jesse Plemons) and Saracen (Zach Gilford) are going to break your heart many times over the new season. Count on it.
It's good to be back in Dillon, even if it's harder to get there than it used to be.

Lights proves not only that it's possible to produce a smart drama with teenage characters, but that a series can be better than the movie that spawned it. For that reason and others, this remains an hour to savor until the final pistol sounds.
Friday Night Lights is delivered with the precision and manner of ethnography - it never condescends.

Let's be honest: Season 3 is a Hail Mary pass for Friday Night Lights, one of those real good TV shows that always seems to have been playing from a touchdown or two behind. Still, win or lose, the show has got game.
It's not often that television with a scope so novelistic -- so ambitious -- comes along, and not often, either, that it yields drama so sterling.
Not since HBO's The Wire has a show juggled so many conflicting and diverse issues like race, money, and class with such staggering insight.
A brilliant season that deserves another and another.
I think the writers have done a fine job setting the table for Season Two and providing those lovely little moments that continue to set the show apart.

The contemplation of such complex questions makes Friday Night Lights a consistently grown-up show, willing to confront fading dreams and rash decisions without quite losing faith in the unpredictable transcendence of everyday life.
Every team has an off season. But despite the reputation of That Bad Thing, Jesse Plemons can hold his head high about FNL season 2. He killed.
In short, it feels like life. The show isn't merely set in the world of West Texas football; it is that world. Watching it, you have a feeling of total immersion -- in the (fictional) town of Dillon.
The subtlety and restraint of the actors, particularly Chandler and Britton, makes the small moments all the more natural and intimate.
Even among the many glaring problems, Friday Night Lights still proved to be better than most dramas on network television.
It helps that Chandler still says more with a few words than most actors say with a monologue.
The show doesn't back away from what happens in the premiere, and by early in episode two, we're at a point where the only way to fix it is to write out the characters involved.
This moving drama remains the finest show on network television, and its return after a low-rated first season ranks as a minor miracle.
For the most part, the show is back in top form, particularly when it comes to the central dynamic between Coach Taylor (Kyle Chandler) and his wife, Tami (Connie Britton).
FNL still does no more than tell life-size stories about life-size people. In a universe of Dirty Sexy Money, that may not be enough, but while it's here, there aren't many better games in town.

I can't imagine what stopped Emmy voters from lavishing this series with nominations this year, unless they failed to realize that it's not, strictly, a sports drama. I also can't imagine why [FNL] isn't a ratings success, except for the same confusion.
The story arcs dare to treat small-town American life in all its solemn complexity. The characters rise above inert cutouts, each following a journey, for better and worse, worth taking.

To hold [FNL] to a measure of realism would be to miss what are its Expressionistic pleasures: the haunting score, the camerawork whose compositions immediately establish that we are in the territory of the most thoughtful kind of melodrama.
Friday Night Lights is beautifully shot, the realism seeping out of it in every scene, from dinner table to football field. Give NBC credit for pouring money into a series like this.
Everyone on Friday Night Lights deserves an Emmy. And true to form for this great unsung show, none of them were even nominated.

This show captures a distinct culture, and the people jockeying for places in it, trying to prove, mostly to themselves, that their lives have value. And so Friday Night Lights has more than almost any network show today.
Kyle Chandler is the new coach, Connie Britton his terrific wife, and Scott Porter the star quarterback injured in the first game of the season. The rest is claustrophobic hope and dread.
Shot docudrama-style with handheld cameras, long single takes and improvisation, it transcends soap and melodrama with rare, spot-on naturalism.
It's the best high school coaching drama since The White Shadow, and deserves a chance.
Between its cinematography, setting, and subject matter, Lights doesn't look a whole lot like anything else on television right now.

Friday Night Lights gets off to a rousing start. Everything about it is vividly drawn, with [Kyle] Chandler excelling as an up-against-it coach whose locker room rallying cry is "Clear eyes. Full hearts. Can't lose."
For all the narrative sincerity and good-looking imagery offered by FNL it is most admirable for its insights into the industry models that shape U.S. entertainment, sports, religion, and education.
Sometimes great television doesn't need a unique hook or an edgy or dark side to be something special; it just needs terrific writing and acting, something this show has an abundance of.
Friday Night Lights is remarkable for many reasons, but the first thing that hits you, in the pilot, is how different it looks and feels from other shows on television.

Earnest, beautifully shot and perhaps more organically religious than anything else in primetime, the series will have its fans but doesn't initially possess the addictive pull required to become a Tuesday-night game-changer.
It feels so close to actual American life that it lacks the gut excitement that would take it over the line into true entertainment. It's a bit dull.

What makes Friday Night Lights compelling is not the football or the cast. It's the accumulation of little details, like the eager faces of the pee-wee players as they meet and respectfully worship the big high-school boys whom they dream of becoming.
If you're not on the edge of your seat during the last 10 minutes of Friday Night Lights you simply don't have a pulse.
The plotlines are predictably full of teen melodrama and small-town angst, but the cast is interesting, and the show's semidocumentary style gives it surprising grit.
The documentary feel of Friday Night Lights is strengthened by the use of a hand-held camera and quick-cut editing.

Lights has a rare ability to portray life in small-town America without being condescending or sentimental. Those are rich fields to explore, and Lights shows promise of doing so with both warmth and intelligence.

Part of the reason Friday Night Lights works its magic on viewers is that Berg's documentary-style stamp gives the show a more mature feel -- it has none of the trappings of a teen drama, none of the sheen of a network series set in a small town.

The performances alone are worth tuning in to see, but watching the bits and pieces come together, and being swept up in the show's powerful emotional pull, can be pure exhilaration. Friday Night Lights is great, heavy-duty, high-impact TV.

[I] find himself at full grovel, crawling toward Nielsen households, begging that they flip on [this show]. The show is terrific -- the most engrossing new drama of the fall season -- but it's also the worst-rated, and that's just not fair.

More than simply being outstanding, Friday Night Lights is an important series because of the way it takes family-friendly television seriously. The issues covered here create the kind of family drama that can bring everybody to the table.

Friday Night Lights is a wonder. It's a big drama, and even seasoned pilot skeptics -- and their bookies, who rank shows based on the odds they'll be canceled -- will have a hard time not getting choked up at tonight's episode.

Compared to the bomb-throwing excitements of other "topical" series, Madam Secretary's comforting politics are not going to set the world on fire. In a world already on fire, that's precisely the point.
Really, the supporting cast is what makes this show work for me.

With the way Election 2016 is going, it's been next to impossible for writers to come up with storylines that stranger than reality. Madam Secretary Season 3 Episode 1 certainly gave it the old college try though.
It was a rather exciting hour and set up a new mystery to be solved this season.

Madam Secretary shines more through its star, Tea Leoni, and its supporting cast, than its stories, which work harder than they probably need to to make the job of secretary of state look interesting.
Leoni gives Elizabeth McCord a savvy, down-to-earth quality that makes her easy to root for.
The world's a mess, but this show's pretty neat.
Perhaps a tad more excitability might have prevented me from having to give this pilot three tries before making it through without falling asleep.
The Veep-ish bits are 10 times better than the sappy West Wing-ish bits.
I would say this show is good. It's not great, but if it can ratchet up the drama about three notches, and I think it can, we will be in for a good time.
A smart and enthralling D.C. drama that resurrects its predecessor's outlook, but still takes on a life of its own.
It has a lot going for it, including the smart and striking Tea Leoni.
My takeaway: Leoni looks the part but this series is like America recognizing Cuba: it's just never gonna happen.

Smartly written and formidably cast, the series... offers a welcome dose of T�a Leoni, female sanity and political heroism to a world perhaps grown weary of broken heroes, twisted ambitions and a universally sardonic view of American government.

If you're a fan of politically-inspired quips, supporting characters with a knack for easing tension with jokes and strong female powerhouses, then Madam Secretary is definitely worth a second watch before you make your final DVR decision.
Madam Secretary does something else that suggests it has more on its mind than entertainment, which is to take on dilemmas without obvious solutions.
Overall, I think there is a ton of potential here but also plenty of room for improvement.
Compared to other Oval Office dramas, Madam Secretary is far less murky than Homeland, far less soapy than Scandal, and, so far, far less interesting than House of Cards and The West Wing.
There's actually quite a bit to sink your teeth into here.

Leoni is charming and confident as the relatable, brilliant and well-meaning McCord, but this isn't a doe eyed dreamer striving to make a world of candy clouds and gum drop forests. There's a toughness to this grounded character.
There's more than enough hope that the pieces are there, and the piece that really matters at this point -- Leoni -- can hold the show down while it finds its direction.
It's a solid cast and a surprisingly good first episode, with its world already well-defined and set to get more hectic as the weeks go by.

Leoni's portrayal of a working mom in power feels both refreshing and on point, never dwelling on the fact that she's a woman with a tough job but instead focusing on the fact that she's really good at it.

Madam Secretary seems terrified the audience will miss something, to the degree that all of the characters might as well be walking around wearing index cards emblazoned with any given scene's subtext glued to their foreheads.
A particularly taut and well-structured pilot episode lays out McCord's essential struggles, while Leoni delivers a calm, cool and wry performance.
